QuestionStem: The three processes below would allow a horticulturist to grow only purple-flowered pea plants for many generations. However, the horticulturist is constrained by time. Select the process that would allow the horticulturist to grow only purple-flowered plants in the shortest amount of time.

options.AnswerText: A. A horticulturist could start by crossing two plants with purple flowers. In each new generation, they should select plants with purple flowers to cross, until all of the plants for several generations have purple flowers.
options.Feedback: Could any of the purple-flowered plants in the first and second generations carry an allele for another flower color?

options.AnswerText: B. A horticulturist could send plant specimens to a lab for genotype analysis, which usually take 1–2 weeks.
options.Feedback: White flowers could appear in future generations if the horticulturist started by allowing a plant with purple flowers to self-pollinate.

options.AnswerText: C. A horticulturist could allow the purple plants to self-pollinate and then separate purple plants from the first generation and allow those plants to self-pollinate.

FinalIncorrectFeedback: Genotype analysis can identify two plants that do not carry the recessive allele for white flower color. All offspring produced using these plants as parents will have only purple flowers for many generations. This analysis can take place over a shorter period of time than growing plants and waiting for them to flower.
